title: Foreign Resident Life Event Exception

scenario_info.name: Foreign Resident Life Event Exception
scenario_info.description: Jessica moved to the UK in 2019 and became a foreign resident for tax purposes. In 2023, her husband passed away. Under the life event exception, she has 6 years from the date of his death to sell her Australian main residence and claim the main residence exemption, despite being a foreign resident.

expected_result.notes: Life event exception + six-year rule = full exemption despite foreign residency

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.110: Foreign residents cannot claim MRE (since 1 July 2020)
Exception: Life event within 6 years - death of spouse, child under 18, or terminal illness
ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule (rental 5.67 years < 6 years)
Jessica can claim MRE despite being foreign resident due to husband's death
Must sell within 6 years of life event (sold 1.5 years after)

property_history.description: Established as main residence with husband
Relocated to UK for work - became foreign resident for tax purposes
LIFE EVENT: Husband passes away. This triggers the life event exception allowing MRE claim within 6 years.

properties.notes: Full exemption. Although Jessica is a foreign resident, the life event exception (husband's death) allows her to claim MRE. Sold within 6 years of life event (1.5 years). Six-year absence rule also satisfied (rental 5.67 years).

user_query: I became a foreign resident in 2019 when I moved to the UK. My husband passed away in 2023. I'm selling my Australian home in 2025. Can I still claim the main residence exemption?
